To
e right honorable my very singular good Lord
e Erle of Essex.

M
r
Bodley to E. Essex Feb
r
[94] [Cop & Ex:]

page.lettertext:
fol.15r
May it please yo
r
good L. when I came to
Middel-
bourgh
, I had some speeche w
t
M
r
Valke
, with whome
I thought it not amisse, to beginne in this order. I
told him
at her
Ma
tie
had enjoined me expressely, to
salute him in her name, and to will him to remember,
what he had signified unto her, about
e Amitie conclu-
ded at his being in
Scotland.
She had occasion to
conjecture, that somwhat els aswell as that, was ether
then contrived, or would be very shortly, when
Coronel
Stuart
should come hither: albeit she had no doubt, but
M
r
Valke for his particular would never yelde to any
practise,
at might turne to her detriment. But if
in
e end it proved otherwise,
e inconvenience of
suche dealinges would falle upon these contreis, and
perhaps so great a part would light upon his shoulders,
as they would not be able to welde
e weight of that
bourden, as bigge, and as large, and as strong as they
were: w
ch
I told him w
t
all she uttered very merely.
For suche a kinde of salutation I thought might
fitte very well w
t
her Ma
ties
deliverie. And so
he tooke it in good part, w
t
humble thankes unto her
Hig
es
at she vouchesafed to thinke upon him: but
yet w
t
earnest protestation,
at nothing had passed
between
e
Scottish King
and them, but a general
revocation of
e ancient leagues and alliances between
e
towne
two contreis. And if any thing els should
be sought at their handes, he was flatte of opinion,
at
they were not to embrace it in honestie, or pollicie:
considering w
at
favo
rs
they had receaved of her
Hig
es
and howe mightie she was, if she would be re-
venged: and
at in Scotland they sawe nothing but
beggerie, wantes, and weakenesse. He also added
other reasons too long
to
relate, but in one among
e
rest, he utterly disliked, to see so many youthes about
e King in his Court, and so fewe of any gravitie.
fol.15v
Coronel Stuart as then was not arrived, but came
to Middelbourgh
e same day: and after suche time as
M
r
Valke had bin w
t
him, he visited me againe, and
signified of him self,
at he perceaved by
e Coronel,
at
he came from
e King, to require
e seale of
e states,
for confirmation of
at League, w
ch
M
r
Brederorde
and he had signed in Scotland: and besides to intreat
for some aide against
e rebels of that contrey: purposing
also, as he thought, to goe from hens into
Germany.
I tooke occasion heereup
o
, to discourse a litle w
t
him, and
to wishe
at their state would be very well advised, w
at
they did in those cases, w
t
out acquainting her Ma
tie
with
their purpose before. For said I to tell yow plainely,
we are thus persuaded of Scottes in
England,
at they
are naturaly inclined to dissimulation and cunning,
and are full of inconstancie: and
at w
ch
yow in good
meaning may be wonne to graunt unto them, will
peradventure be abused to yo
r
very great preudice.
It might be also in continuance,
at they would falle to
complaine of her Hig
es
dealinges w
t
e King, w
ch
if
in every point she have not applied to their humou-
rous dispositions, they would undoubtedly disgrace, and
happely seeke to drawe
e states to a like dislike of her
proceedinges. Wherew
t
I made some rehersall, howe
highly
e King was beholding to her Ma
tie
and howe
unkindly for his part he had requited it hitherto:
concluding therupon,
at if
e King and these contreis
should joine in any action against her Ma
ties
good li-
king, it would at last come to light, howe secretly soever
it were caried for
e time. And then her Ma
ties
puis-
sance, and
e Love
at is borne by her subjectes unto her,
being duly considered, it was easie to foresee, howe soone
she might be able, to meete w
t
his designes, and so pulle
downe
at saile wherunto he trusteth most. And as for
these contreis, she hath gotten in her custodie their cau-
tionarie townes, w
ch
are
e keies of all their doares,
fol.16r
that they can not sturre about their buisnesse, but by
her favo
r
and permission. This commu-
nication I had w
t
him as by way of discourse, and up
o
suche occasions as he himself ministred, w
t
out geving
any token of
e lest suspition,
at I had any notice of
e
Coronels errand: but rather, as if I knewe him so well,
at I was throughly assured, he would bend all his service, to
doe very good offices. As fitte occasions are presen-
ted, I will also deale w
t
some others, according to their
qualities, to
e same or like effect. But
e chiefest have
bin absent, at
e mariage of
Co. Hohenlo
, and are but
newly nowe returned, nor I have had no opportunitie
to see
e Coronel himself. As touching my message
to
e
General states
, I have written w
at
is done unto my
L. T
re
r
, and of somwhat els besides, wherof heereinclosed
I send yow a copie,
and so I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage Fe
b
5 1594
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
